description.text: Heavy Duty Control Horns, print 100% Solid, Machine Head Screw is  a M3 x 30mm with a M3 Locknut Tried And Tested On Planes Up to 46 size IC Planes, they are better using ABS rather Than PLA, But The PLA ones seem to be ok on plane 20 size as the PLA is a bit brittle when printed.
This is my head.

A pair of squared spiral chambers inside a block.  You fill it up with colored water, and then when you flip it upside-down you can watch it go in circles.
Status:  Printed and works.  Flow is quite visible even without remelting faces.  I will print another and try remelting soon.
Print, drill holes, put colored water into holes, seal.

description.text:
EDIT: Two additional ducts just added. Improved_duct_4 works reasonably well at 0.15 mm layer height and is well-tested. Improved_duct_5 is just created to distribute cooling along two axes (the directed perforations towards the nozzle are inspired by the digital solar clock, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1068443) All the FreeCAD source and further information is here:
https://github.com/imarin2/ProtoHead_v6 The original Protohead v4 is here:
https://github.com/imarin2/ProtoHead_v4 The alternative PCB for either Protohead v4 or Protohead v6 is here:
https://github.com/imarin2/Protohead_PCB_v4_FAB_24V The PCBs are designed with KiCAD and can be manufatured with a FABtotum. Full source available in the repositories. You may need this KiCAD library:
https://github.com/imarin2/FABHeadLibraries The Heads run this firmware:
https://github.com/imarin2/ProtoHead

Ordinary breadboard

This is my version of the awesome push drill / pump drill idea from Performance 3D LLC and also modeled by speedy777.
The model is created totally from scratch in Autodesk Inventor.
It was a personal challenge to see if I could model the screw and get it all to fit together nicely.
It works nicely and is excellent for drilling holes in PCBs (printed circuit boards).

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

100%

Notes: Print at high density. Use a brim/raft for the drill itself, so that it doesn't break away when it gets higher. The other parts do not need it. Depending on your printer and temperature, you may need scaffolding in the spherical hole in the bottom of the drill. I found that without scaffolding, it tended to collapse inward a bit too much, but the scaffolding is quite hard to remove.
Designed in AutoDesk Inventor.  The drill was used to cut the inside of the collar, but had to be scaled up slightly to create a free fit -- that was the challenging part!

author: marcosyarza

title: X endstop mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is the X endstop that I'm currently using for my Folgertech 2020 Prusa i3.  It is robust enough that it will not move unintentionally, and the printhead carriage cannot hit the mount before the switch contacts the motor.  I modified it to clear the carriage, even if you are using the 4-bearing version of the prusa x carriage, and so that the lower screw hole is not blocked by the endstop sensor board.
The only downside I've found is that I am losing a tiny amount of print area even with it pushed up against the side piece of the x assembly, so I'll eventually tweak it about to address that.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2, but 0.3 should be fine too

Infill:

30% or better, for strength.

Notes: It is currently set to mount on the right, like the original FolgerTech Prusa 2020 i3 endstop. If you want to mount it on the left, simply mirror it before printing.

title: Another MK5 Dual Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is about my supervisor's idea, now we had a DC motor for MK5 extruder, and we are waiting for the mk6 nema 17 motor, so in awhile, we want to try it on our DC motor and see how it work and we can use it later. description.text:
I designed these bins for small parts storage to fit in card catalog style cabinet drawers I happened to have. The protruding tab on top has some angled rails for sliding in a descriptive label.
At first I was printing these out solid until I realized that was using too much filament. Under the "pattern" dropdown box in the Customizer are options for cutting out a pattern in the sidewalls so the containers can use less material with the added bonus of being able to see the small parts contained inside.
"Hex" is very cool looking but can be taxing for the computer to build the STL. Your mileage may vary getting this to work in Customizer but you can always download the source and run it locally in OpenSCAD. Also it takes a long time to print since the extruder head has to draw a profile for all of the wire mesh.
"Rect" should print much faster but your printer will have to do a lot of bridging.
2015-10-20: Updated with an option to provide pillar support to the "Rect" pattern for improved printing.

title: Levavasseur Whistle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Imagine taking the cross section of a standard referee's whistle and the revolving it about an axis to form a toroidal shaped sound cavity - that's what Robert Levavasseur did when he patented this whistle in 1956. Word has it that in testing a giant 6ft version of this type of whistle, the sound was so loud that it ruptured the internal tissues of Levavasseur and two of his colleagues. This whistle is a little simpler (and smaller) than the version in Levavasseur's patent (http://www.google.com/patents/US2755767). While this version does whistle, I'm sure a lot could be done to optimize the sound. In any case, it will certainly grab the players' attention out on the field!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Update: I've added a second version (whistle_1.stl) which seems to whistle a little more reliably. It has built-in supports designed specifically fro 0.1mm layer thickness. You can probably print this whistle with 0.2mm layers, but the smoother the internal surface, the better it will whistle. Note that the built-in supports are designed specifically for printing with 0.1mm layers - using 0.2mm layers may make them difficult to remove. I've included two STL file versions - one with a break-away support structure built-in and one without that will require you to turn on supports. The one with supports also has bridging ribs on the inside of the torus that don't need to be broken away. I recommend using the version with built-in supports because the slicer generated supports will be devilishly hard to remove and won't leave as smooth a finish. The STL file without supports, though, makes it easier to see how the whistle is constructed.

Whistles are really hard to make whistle properly.  I've designed simpler whistles, printed the same design twice and had one copy whistle great while the other copy just wheezed.  I went through a lot of iterations to get this goofy version to whistle.  A tenth of a millimeter here or there will significantly alter the sound, and surface smoothness is very important.  I've included the original Solidworks file  and it'd be great to see other people improve upon this design.

comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: Whistles are difficult to 3D print because the air passages need to be really smooth to keep the flow laminar.  This whistle is particularly tricky because the airflow runs across the print layer lines (rather than along the layer lines like most whistles) and any surface roughness will disturb the flow.  First make sure that you have cleaned up the whistle nicely and have removed all bits of support structure.  I've found that cleaning up the lip edge with a pocket knife can help generate a clean sound.  One other thing I discovered is that if you wet the whistle (and then shake it out) it often produces a sharper tone - just like licking your lips before whistling with your mouth.  The theory is that the thin layer of water smooths out the surface to help maintain laminar flow.

description.text: My design of a dual extruder mod for the Lulzbot TAZ. This puts the budaschnozzles as close as possible (40mm center to center). and nearly all of the build platform is accessible to both extruders, once you alter the firmware for extra y travel. originally discussed here: http://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=66 UPDATE 6-25-2013: added a supported version of the motor moved extruder. just cut the support away after you print (thanks to lulzbots design for the help with the support)

print two of the motor moved extruder bodies. all other parts are from the greg wades extruder that lulzbot uses. you need the idler and washer. http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/printed_parts/main_fleet/jonaskuehling_gregs_wade_ao/extruder_idler-washer/ and of course the heringbone gears. http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/printed_parts/main_fleet/herringbone_large_gear/ http://devel.lulzbot.com/TAZ/printed_parts/west_fleet/herringbone_small_gear/ It's a little tough to get the motor screws tightened with the gear in place, but it can be done. you will also have to cut the excess threads from the hobbed bolt, and likely remove the thumb screw caps and one of the springs. print the extruder mount and mount the 2 assembled extruders and budaschnozzles. wires for the nozzles should come up from between the extruders. print the adjustment block, probably will need support material. Install M4 nuts in the sockets in the adjustment block. now that you are done printing the parts, remove the extruder mount. Remove the 4 screws on the bottom of the x carriage. slide the adjustment block up the x carriage until the screw holes line up, you will likely need to file some parts to get it to fit but it should be tight. replace the 4 M3 screws with longer ones to bolt everything together. add 2 M4 bolts or set screws pointing up. they will push against the dual extruder mount to raise the second nozzle to get them both at the same level. wire everything up, and upgrade the firmware configuration.h and configuration_adv.h . don't forget another PTFE or HDPE feed tube. And I still need a good dual spool holder. ALSO- I strongly suggest upgrading the 3 linear bearings in the X carriage to ball bearings. the excess weight of the extra extruder will accelerate the wear of the solid bearings.

This extruder is based on "RepRap Universal Mini Extruder by adrian-bowyer" Labitrude 1.0 Beta 2 -> Labitrude 1.0 Beta 3 Changes:
Air vent in fixed block and base is changed.
Driven gear changed
Version numbers on some parts. The main differences is that the Labitrude extruder is based on materials that we (*)"The reprap group @ Labitat", already have on our shelves.
This means that it is designed for:
  • 3mm filament
  • Nema17 motors
  • "608" barrings.
  • The need for glueing the duct is removed, but both fan clips must be glued on.
  • The air duct is changed, and partly integrated in the fixed block.
    1. 3mm studding used to get at secure grip at the drive, and easy to disassemble again.
  • gear ratio changed to 30/11 (needs verified testing)
    • If you need 1.75 mm filament, or if the compact design is important, you really should consider the original "Reprap Mini Extruder by adrian-bowyer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7975 (*) Labitat is a Danish hackerspace in the heart of Copenhagen - Further information about Labitat can be found at http://www.labitat.dk

title: Decepticon Cookie Cutter and Stamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Decepticon Logo cookie cutter and stamp.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Step 1 - Find an SVG I got my SVG from the Transformers Wiki. Load SVG in Inkscape. Step 2 - Mold Generation Using the Inkscape to OpenSCAD extension, export base and details is separate OpenSCAD files. Make the height 3mm when exporting. Step 3 - Blade Generation Convert the Background to a Path.
In config set offset size to 1mm.
Use path offset for gap. Duplicate, change offset size to 3mm.
Use path offset for high portion of cutter (the blade).
Change path color and send to back. Use path difference between original shape and offset shape to.
Export differenced path. Step 4 - Cutter Handle Generation Undo differencing.
Delete inner path, duplicate outer path.
In config set offset size to 6mm.
Use path offset. Change offset path's color, send to back.
Select both the old outer path and the new 6mm offset path.
Use path difference again. Export new differenced path. Step 5 - Assemble in OpenSCAD In a new OpenSCAD file make using directives to bring in the functions from the other four files Call the functions as shown in each file. Place the background object on z=0 and the foreground above is at z=3. Make sure the cutter portions are overlapping and unioned.
Make sure there is a clear gap between cutter and stamp. I have a pre-designed hollow handle (I may upload it sometime in the future),
that I use also, but a handle is pretty much a 3mm tall rectangular prism.

There have been a influx of hook objects, so I figured I should throw my design into the mix.  I recently moved into a room with wire shelves in the (smallish) closet.  Wanting to maximize my storage options, I designed these hangers to hook onto the shelves.  The hooks have a diameter of 30 and 50mm.  The attachment point is made for 6-7mm diameter rod, but the hook could be scaled for any other size.  It is a tight press-on fit, so the hook does not come of the shelf accidentally.  The hook has a 5x10mm rectangular cross-section.
I will try to upload photos when I get home and time allows (The move is still in progress).
The three attached files each contain two hooks, the hook diameter given in the file title.

I printed both sizes in ABS with a couple extra shells and light infill.  This has worked for holding a bath towel or pair of jeans.  I have not attempted to find the limit, but they are stronger and stiffer than I expected.  For even greater strength, use zero extra shells and 100% infill.
Let me know if there are any suggestions for improvement or new sizes.

This part replaces the acrylic Y-Axis foot which comes with the Ordbot and adds support to the rather flimsy metal plate which holds the belt idler. One simple part which does not interfere with any of the printers workings. Improves belt tension and adjustably. Designed to work with my Y Motor Support
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106279

• Print part (Printed with a 3 wall perimeter at .2mm layer height. 20% infill)

  • Remove the stock acrylic foot and retain bolts and pulley idler plate.

  • Insert Nylock nut into underside of foot and attach the plate and idler pulley to foot.

  • Insert 2 M5 t slot nuts into underside of Y axis Makerslide.

  • Slide onto end of makerslide and re-assemble belt.

  • Tension and tighten bolts.

comments.author: Maffo_3d

comments.text: I usually avoid printing with support, but in this case I thoght it was the lesser evil. Printing in vertical thin object often produce deformed pieces due to the fact there's no time to cool down the previous layer so you have to made tricks (as you suggest)  to keep the hot end away for more time or use a fan, that is good for PLA but not for ABS. The second matter is related to the fact that, in this case, layer printed with vertical orientation potentially makes a mechanically weaker piece. Third, with support, you can print one piece at a time, if you want.

description.text: My wife lost her 4 in 1 meditool at work which she used to open the seals on bottles. Found the tool online, but could only be purchased in bulk, so i went on a mission to create one. I used Google SketchUp and converted to STL. At the moment, it's a 3 in 1: opens seals, picks the cotton out with the hook end, and the end can be used as a flat edge when counting pills. It's missing the pill tweezer blades that the original has. It works! Also available on Shapeways for purchase! https://www.shapeways.com/product/GGQ5RK78J/pharmacy-meditool

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Should not matter, but .3 is fine

Infill:

50% infill to remain flexible

Notes: Printed with teeth facing up, so supports are a must. I've added super glue around the 2 teeth to strengthen as well as super glue where the walls meet. I also used a lighter to slightly soften and then squeeze the teeth with needle nose pliers to get the teeth thinner and sharper.

remixed_from.author: MAKERFAM
remixed_from.title: ArduSat - The Arduino CubeSat Satellite (full scale model)

description.text:
I thought this was a pretty neat model, but I didn't like the idea of using support to print the double sided boards. I split the boards through the center using Netfab. I also used 8-32 all-thread to tie it all together instead of the plastic rods. I added hex spacers as well. You'll need 4 of the 1Q spacers to to mount the camera to the angle (you'll have to drill 4 holes for in the angle mount) then double sticky tape or glue to mount the angled camera. I also included the spacers needed to space the boards out. You'll need 4 20mm spacers, and 8 each of the 10mm and 15mm spacers, 2 cameras and one of everything else. I did away with the printed up-rights, with the all thread you don't need them. 4 100mm pieces of 8-32 all thread, I tapped the existing holes in the bottom and used a friction fit on the top. It's not perfect, but it works and I think it looks pretty cool.  Note: the flat frame stl file is the same as the original file and it includes the 4 rods and the 4 uprights that I did not use, all you need is the top and bottom frame pieces.
YMMV
TiM

description.text:
This allows you to mount a 40mm fan onto the stock fan shroud for a quick improvement in cooling. You need:
  • A 40mm Fan with M4 mounting holes
  • 2x M4 bolts [length = fan depth + (7 to 15mm)]
  • 2x Original M3 fan mounting bolts
  • EITHER:
    2x M4 nuts (clearance holes might need drilling out)
     1x M4 tap and tap handle
    • Both the nuts and tap can be used, but it's not neccessary Pictures show how to use the nuts and tapped threads. Let me know if there's any improvements I can make

Doesn't Matter

This OpenSCAD script will generate a simple fixture to hold several WIMUv3 units while they charge, featuring internal space for cables and possibly a base station or powered USB hub To do
implement cable runs, finger cutouts, uUSB male plug holes
use actual values for wimu dimensions
use rounded corners
add WIMU numbers?
add holes so status LEDs can be seen?
add tyndall logo?
add option to add mouse-ears to prevent curling during printing Warning
This is nowhere near complete! but it should still make a nice divided tray or small square object holder Note
Changes from previous versions:
0.1
  • First attempt

You can use this as a parametric recess box/tray maker. To do this:
  • Open .SCAD file and go to the UserVariables* section
  • Set the size of the items to want to put into it to wimu_x & wimu_y
  • set the wimu_tolerance value to something slightly above 0 so you can easily remove/insert the items
  • set the cavity_depth (how deep the recess is), wall_t_ext (how thick the walls around the edges are), wall_t_sep (how thick the walls are between each cell) to suitable values
  • Choose a how many rows and columns you would like using wimu_rows & wimu_cols
  • Recompile, generate .stl and print!

author: alehp

description.text:
This thing allows for more options then using a setscrew.
.
Adjusting can be done by moving the calipers slide up/down to the desired z-hight. Very usefull if:
-you want to add a glass plate or mirror tile onto the heated bed.
-you want to start a print at other z-hight then Zero.
-you want resuming a failed print at unknown last good z-hight, measure the z-hight of the last printed layer using the caliper
.
Adjusting can be done by moving the calipers slide up/down to the desired z-hight. If you are using allready any kind of z-trigger modification, this can be combined with the adjustable digital caliper as long as it hits the switch at the motor mount corner position.
.
Hint:
If:
-you are fine with a new fixed position for a adding a glass plate only
-this method is to hard for you to do
-you are missing a digital caliper for this purpose
.
Then take the z-switch mount with 3 fixed positions:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1070894
.
Let the slider rest in the desired positon.
The high friction of the slide inside the caliper helds it in position.
If it urges you build another fixation solution anytime later. At the absolut lowest usefull z-hight "z-min=0"can be set pushing the zero-button.
Nothing to change with your settings in the slicer software.
It works using edge of the motormount triggering the z-switch as the stock version does. The files:
Parts are in groups for the slider and the upper and lower holder.

Parts:
  • cheap digital caliper (shaft 16mm wide, the big claws round about 12mm)
  • some screws and nuts M3(with flat hats recommended), depends on which parts you are going to use
  • Depending on the shift you are making with the slider it needs expanding the wires.
    Depicted above is a pair of connectors available from the RC-equipment but others from the regular PC stuff will do as well.
    • Assemblation:
    Please note: before you unmount the z-switch check the size and shape of your caliper.
    The particular used one caliper exists in many other brands but they are often the same size and origin. The holders can be screwed on using long screws M3. This requieres you to bore some holes and cut the threads in the frame. (prefered methode).
    If you can not cut the threads use some nuts (self locking) with the screws. If you want no holes/threads in the frame the stacked parts can be assembled using short screws. Make the thread in the plastic by turning the screws. The assembled parts can be glued onto the frame using thin double sided tape.
    Don't glue or screw the slider onto the frame ;-) Clamp the upper and lower end of the caliper with the holders. There are groves the ends have to rest in.
    Attach the slider with the calipers slider. Should have a very tight fit. No wiggle please. Put the holders onto the frame, holding the slider part between the caliper and the frame.
    The lower holder uses the existing holes next to the lower edge of the frame.
    Glue/screw the holder on.
    Put some protectiv matarial between the slider and the frame (ca. 1mm thick)
  • No adjustment on the bed screws required!
    All adjustments can be done using the digital readout only.
    • Assuming you have the print bed hight untouched:
    -Rise the z-axis a few millimeters at least.
    -Cover the bed surface with a sheet of (protective) paper before you go to the next step.
    -Move the slider to the position next to what the stock switch mount has.
    Hint: find the threaded holes in the frame.
    To be safe start a little higher than the old position was.
  • Check the nozzle hight while moving toward the bed surface!
    Be prepared to react quickly.
    • -Adjust the Zero hight by lowering the z-axis manually (rotary encoder or software in Pronterface/Repetier-Host) until you have triggered the stop or hear the switch klick.
  • If the nozzle touches the paper on the bed but has not triggered the switch push the switch by hand IMMEDIATLY (again when the head goes down the second time) or push the hidden reset button on the controler board or power off.
    Start over with a higher slider hight.
    • -When you have set the hight next to the touch down remove the protective sheet and do the fine calibration.
    -When you have finished adjusiting Zero push the zero-button on the caliper.
    -For the case the battery runs out please note the reading on the ruler.
    This will give you an easier restart after exchanging the batterie. Application:

  • Please note: No adjustment on the bed screws required!
    All adjustments can be done using the digital readout only.
    -When you have added a glass or want a higher start position move the slider to the desired hight. Use the digital readout.
    -When you have mounted the glass on the bed, don't trust the thickness value taken from the description. Measure the glass thickness first or do the calibration again having the glass mounted.
    -To be sure note the new value for later return to Zero if you have hit the zero- button accidently or the battery has emptied.
    If you keep the glass on the bed you may push the zero button at this new hight.

  • If you want go back to the old zero hight make the bed surface free and slide the calipers slider down untill the display shows "000".
    -If you have additionally reset the zero hight meanwhile with a new glass or similar move the slider further down the value you have noted earlier.

This item is a top water frog fishing lure that I printed using silicone caulk.  
The rear legs are thin enough to move when pulled through the water for a little leg action.  
I made my version using slic3r to generate the g-code from the posted STL file.  My printer is a CNC converted Sieg X3 with a homemade plunger type extruder set up on a fourth axis stepper motor.

For items such as this frog that have a thick body I typically print with 100% fill and wait about 24 hours for the outside to cure.  After the 24 hours I cut a slot in the body and squeeze out the uncured silicone.  This generally works better than a fractional fill, however, I have had some success with fractional fills also.

This model is designed to hold 3 Sleeved Commander/EDH decks. Each deck is bound together in a removable card stack that can be used as a dealer shoe. This design is meant to allow you to keep the box in your bag and pull the drawer out for deck selection.

Yet another project I made for myself for when I got my 3D printing up and running. Due to a mess up on my end, the printer was pushed back.  
This should be scaled to be printed as is, and has a spot in the back to house a 3M command hook backing, to allow you to stick it anywhere. It [Command hook slot] does have a chunk of plastic that needs to be snapped out. On top of that, there is a spot in the front to hold the USB dongle for the headset, along with a hook at the bottom to hold the USB charging cable when its not hooked up to the headset.  
Again, this is not something I have personally printed, and as such, I am unsure how well it will print.

title: R10 Quadrotor Custom Landing Gear Foot

description.text:
UPDATE Landing Gear is a success! Very strong. be sure to acetone treat the legs for optimal strength. land too hard, and you will bend the frame. i took a 5ft landing drop on grass carrying a gopro without damage! The R10 Quadrotor came with terrible landing gear, so i decided to make my own modification. This is a 3d Print tested part, and the hole sizing should be just about perfect for you. i sliced in cura, and printed at 20% Infill. It uses the same bolts that comes with the R10, just unbolt, and bolt these On! The nut is captive, so you don't need anything but an allen key. More parts for this quadrotor to come, including battery relocation mount, and Go Pro Hero 3 Mount
and a Ultrasonic Sensor relocation mount. I designed this in OpenSCAD which i know nothing about, but am trying to learn.

Instructions: Print Two Regular, Print Two Mirrored.
Attach to quadrotor and use 8MM Shafts of the length you prefer.
I used 8mm carbon shafts and it works great! The Feet are still a prototype, but are very strong, again designed for 8mm shafts (actual diameter 7.75mm)

title: Rhythm Cube Machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Please check out V2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1178226 I have been working on this projects for a couple of days.
The idea is to build a percussion machine where you can create customized rhythms. The three different sized blocks provide different pitch when stroked while the twelve holes inside the spinning wheel controls the timing of each strike. There are more than 1700 possible combinations.
The hole design is made from 9 pieces, and fits in a 10x10x10cm box, what made the challenge much harder need improvement:
Top cross brace has to be lock in place. change connection type.
Finger swing range ; push connection between finger and wheel. Gears are a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41246

description.text: Just a nice Spiral Coaster to put your drinks on.  :)
Like geometry? Like drinking too? Print yourself some Geometric Coasters then!  :)

Here is a new twist on the old Fly swatter we have all had or are about to have ;)
I had a few flies hanging around my house that just would not go away and didn’t want to buy a fly swatter so I decided to design one with a little character added to it. I printed mine out of PLA but this would a perfect application for a flexible filament or a printer with duel extruders so the fly could be a different color. This is a pretty hefty swatter, I was actually killing them dead in their tracks while they were flying.
After the print is done just use an old metal coat hanger to make the handle. I cut the hook off just below the twisted wire and then straightened the wire out with pliers, looped the hand end of the handle around my caliper box and twisted the wire for the middle section and then cut the two end even and bent then so they lined up with the two holes on the swatter and pushed the ends in. you may need a little epoxy to hold the two pieces together (I did not but each printer is different). 
This fly swatter is a little larger than the common household swatter, but that just helps your aim a bit better. If you think it will be a bit big then you can just scale it down in you slicing software but just remember that there are two holes where the wire handle is attached and those will shrink too, so they would have to be drilled out back to the right size.
Let me know what you think and if you print one I hope you can find the time to take a picture of it and load it up as a make.

comments.text:

Expensive (TPU) way to refurbish your old fly swatter but way more fun than a trip to the hardware store for a new one!!

Connect SLR lenses to GuerillaBeam projectors or other devices. Lens adapters included:
  • Pentax PK
  • Canon EF
  • Nikon F
  • Minolta SR
  • Praktica B
  • Contax C/Y
  • M42 (some scraping/glueing might be necessary)
    • All adapters are robust, easy to print, and feature the same GuerillaBeam screw mount.
  • "53x3" threads with 90 degree flank angles
  • Outer-D: 61mm.
  • Effective length: Lens mount FFD minus 37mm.
    • see also:
  • GuerillaBeam slide holder
  • lens caps for converted lenses
  • open-source GuerillaBeam extension tube

• Remove all blobs on the inside, as the bayonet adapters should be accurate to 0.15mm
  • Carefully clean your print. Lenses don't like dust.
  • Inspect for defects. Prints with huge defects should only be used for light lenses.

  • You can use an Edding 780 gloss paint marker for the lens mounting index

  • With M42-adapters you might have to scrape some material away for perfect fit.
    Adding a drop of glue can be convenient, by preventing free rotation of M42 lenses.

Most GuerillaBeam designs are on Thingiverse, tagged with GuerillaBeam. If you are missing something, please feel free to contact me. Advertisement:
You can order GuerillaBeam parts and kits at the official GuerillaBeam webpage (worldwide shipping!).
